description.narrative: Output 4.3: Children, caregivers and communities in selected districts apply optimal nutrition and care practices, and seek preventive, promotive and curative nutrition services, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Community-Based Management Of Acute Malnutrition, Infant And Young Child Feeding, Micronutrients, Nutrition And Hiv, Nutrition â€“ General, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 4: Infants, young children and mothers have increased and equitable use of nutritional services and improved nutrition and care practices, with a focus on stunting.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 4.3: Children, caregivers and communities in selected districts apply optimal nutrition and care practices, and seek preventive, promotive and curative nutrition services

description.narrative: High impact proven community level nutrition interventions for the prevention of all forms of malnutrition were successfully delivered with UNICEF technical and financial support resulting in an increased number (152,000 in 2018 to 360,160 in 2019) of primary caregivers of children aged 0-23 months reached with infant and young child counselling. Further, UNICEF supported 44% of boys and girls 6-59 months in receiving two annual doses of vitamin A supplementation (up from 34% in 2018). | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of adolescent girls and boys who received services for the prevention of overweight and obesity

Number of children aged 6-59 months with SAM who are admitted for treatment
